description: Variation of Condition 2 (Approved Plans), Condition 5 (Cycle Storage), Condition 10 (Fans, Louvres, Ducts, Plant or External Lighting) and Condition 11 (Refuse Storage) of Planning Permission ref 17/12088/FUL (Partial demolition of 11-13 Thames Street (with the retention of the Listed facade) and construction of a five storey attached building to provide retail (A1) at ground floor level and 10 x 2 bed and 16 x 1 residential units (C3) above) for alterations to elevations and internal layout.
decision_conditions: Notwithstanding Section 55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), the ground floor retail unit shall only be used for retail and for no other purposes whatsoever (including any other purposes falling within Class E of the Schedule to the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (or any provision equivalent to that class in any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification).Reason: The acceptability of the development is highly dependent upon the exact nature of the use of the site and other uses, whether within the same use class or permitted by the General Permitted Development Order, are unlikely to be acceptable in planning terms.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level (excluding any works of demolition), samples and/or manufacturers specifications of the following materials shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority:External bricksStone cladding, bands and cappingRenderMortarWindow glass (including shopfront windows)Door and window frames (including shopfront doors and windows)Balcony screens and balustradesRailingsSignageRainwater goodsGround level pavingThe development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved samples and specifications.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level (excluding any works of demolition), detailed drawings at a scale of 1:10 or 1:20 of the following features shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority:Key junctions/intersectionsFacade projectionsRecesses and revealsWindows and doorsShopfront features (e.g. pilasters, glazing bars and frames)Any other decorative featuresThe development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cycle parking facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 35% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy SI2 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the Written Scheme of Investigation for an Archaeological Watching Brief authored by Touchstone Archaeology and dated 7 February 2020. This condition will not be discharged until the programme for post-investigation assessment and subsequent analysis, publication, dissemination and deposition of resulting material has been completed in accordance with the programme set out in the approved document.Reason: To ensure that matters of archaeological interest can be recorded in accordance with policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM12 of the LDF Core Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a flood preparation and evacuation plan shall be drawn up and then circulated to all residents of the development on an annual basis. The plan shall reference up-to-date UK Government emergency flood advice.Reason: To mitigate the risks associated with flooding of the site, in accordance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a public realm improvement plan for the highway located immediately to the north of the site (Bishops Hall) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The plan shall include a lighting scheme and resurfacing works.The approved plan shall then be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development.Reason: To preserve the character and appearance of the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area, in accordance with policies DM12 and DM13 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts or external lighting other than those shown on the approved plans shall be installed on the building unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The refuse and recycling facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a delivery and service plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved plan.Reason: To ensure proper delivery and service management in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policyT7 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with the Non-Road Mobile Machinery ("NRMM") Regulations and the inventory of all NRMM used on the site shall be maintained and provided to the local planning authority upon request.Reason: To reduce the emissions of construction and demolition, in accordance with the Control of Dust and Emissions during Construction and Demolition SPG 2014.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the retail unit to which this permission relates, a scheme for an active ground floor window frontage to Bishops Hall and Thames Street shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The scheme should not include the installation of window vinyls, graphics, shuttering or any other form of design that prevents views into and out of the shop. The window frontage shall then be maintained in accordance with the approved scheme.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations17 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. One neutral letter of representation received  Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a dormer roof extension and installation 2nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.Application SiteThe site comprises mid terrace dwelling. Planning History24/01777/CPU - Conversion of existing garage into a habitable space, erection of roof extension with  a rear dormer and juliet balcony. Installation of 2nos front roof lights. Refused 13.09.24Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer comment : The proposal seeks  approval for the erection of a rear dormer roof extension and installation of 2nos front rooflights to facilitate aloft conversion. The proposed rear dormer would have a length of 4.166m, width 2.23m and depth 2.185m with a flat roof. Whilst the proposed rear dormer  would be appropriately set in from the sides and eaves  of the roofslope, it would not be appropriately set down from the ridge line of the existing roof by at least 500mm as set out in the recommendations of Policy Guidance 39. In addition, Officers note that  due to the siting of the house the rear elevation of the dwelling  has the prominence of a front elevation  within  the street scene  and  therefore would  be highly visible from Northweald Lane. Officers note that whilst there are other examples of rear dormers within the  vicinity residential area they  relate to either detached or semi detached properties  and where the rear elevation is not visible from the streetscene. , The proposed materials would relate well to those of the existing dwelling. The proposed development is considered unacceptable in terms of scale, form and design, It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character  or appearance of the area  as a result of the proposals. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

Condition 2 (Construction Management Plan) of planning permission 22/02123/PAMA states:Prior to commencement of any development on site, a Construction Management Plan detailing the following:(a)	Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b)	Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c)	Signing system for works traffic.(d)	Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(e)	Means of enclosure of the site.(f)	Wheel washing equipment.(g)	The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(h)	The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.shall be submitted to the planning authority for written agreement. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the construction management plan, which shall be maintained throughout the entire construction period.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Officer comment: The submitted information is considered to be acceptable. It is noted that the RBK's Environmental Health Officer and Highways Engineer raised no objections to the proposal.As such, the details submitted in relation to Condition 2 are hereby approved.  Condition 3 (Noise Assessment Report) of planning permission 22/02123/PAMA states:Before the development is commenced a scheme shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority to demonstrate that the noise level of 35 dB LAeq,16 hour in living rooms and bedrooms during the daytime (0700 to 2300 hours) and 30 dB LAeq,8 hour during the night time (2300 to 0700 hours) in bedrooms, in accordance with BS8233:2014, shall not be exceeded. Noise levels in bedrooms should also not normally exceed 45 dB LAmax,F more than 10 times during the night time. Where these levels cannot be met with windows open appropriate acoustic ventilation should be provided so that the room can be sufficiently ventilated. The acoustic performance of any passive vent, variable speed mechanical air supply unit or whole house ventilation must be sufficient to ensure that the noise level standards given above are not compromised. Once agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority the approved details shall be installed prior to the development being occupied and retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Officer comment: It is noted that the RBK's Environmental Health Officer recommended discharge of Condition 3. As such, the details submitted in relation to Condition 3 are hereby approved.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with installation of 1no. front rooflight to facilitate loft conversionConsultation6 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: It is noted that a number of properties have amended the roof to hip to gable such as No. 79 and No. 84  Somerset Avenue. Whilst the proposed rear dormer would not strictly comply with Policy Guidance 39 of the residential design SPD as it has not been set in at both side, officers note there are a number of  dormers visible with the streetscene.  The proposed dormer would not be readily visible and would be tiled to blend in with the existing roof reducing the visual impact. The catslide element would also be retained. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. A condition will be applied should permission be granted to ensure any side facing windows are obscured glazing and non opening unless the parts of the window which can be opened are more than 1.7 metres above the floor of the room in which the window is installed.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations8 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. In response to the initial neighbour consultation , 1 letter of representation was received which is neutral in content.  Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for  the erection of a single storey rear and side return extension and rear piggyback roof extension to facilitate loft conversion. Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.Planning History24/01291/HOU - Erection of single storey rear and side extension and rear piggy back roof extension to facilitate loft conversion. Refused 04.10.24Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer comment : The proposal seeks approval for the erection of a single storey rear and side return extensions and rear piggyback roof extension to facilitate a roof extension. Officers note the proposed single story piggyback gable loft extension above the main volume of the house would be set back by 4m (wall to wall measurement) and therefore would be compliant with Policy Guidance 40 in the Residential Design SPD.The proposed development also includes a single storey rear and side return extension. The proposed side extension would be set back from the front elevation of the dwelling and set down to a new proposed ground floor level projecting a depth of 118m and width of 1.13m. It would present a single aspect glazed roof for its entire length with an eaves height of 2.18m and maximum pitch height of 3m from the new proposed lower ground floor level. The flank side wall would be constructed in brick and its rear elevation together with the partial side return would be glazed.The proposed single storey rear extension would project a depth of 4m from the original rear elevation projecting beyond the proposed extension and would have a width of 6.15m. It would have a dual aspect pitch roof with an eaves height of 3m which is compliant with the Residential Design SPD and a maximum pitch height of 5.12m from the proposed lower ground floor level. Whilst this proposed pitch height would be contrary to policy guidance, Officers note other examples of dual pitch roof design of rear extensions within the immediate vicinity. In this context and with the creation of a lower floor level, the proposed design is considered to be acceptable. The proposed side return of the proposed western elevation together with the proposed rear and eastern elevations would be timber clad. Officers note the proposed rear elevation would present sliding doors set back within a recess. At first floor level on the rear elevation the existing central window is to be removed. A perforated brick pattern feature would be introduced on the right side and a corner/wrap around window on the left side where the return glazing facing towards neighbouring no 72 would be opaque glazing limiting outlook. In addition, the rear elevation of the proposed piggyback would present a large single window. The roofslope would accommodate 3nos new rooflights on the western slope and a single rooflight on the eastern slope.The proposed materials would relate well to those of the existing dwelling.Within the context of the existing built form on site and the siting of the single storey rear and side extension, it is considered that the proposal would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwellinghouse and that it would acceptable from a character and design perspectiveNeighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The principal property to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property at nos 72 and 76 Deacon Road.Officer Comment:  Officers have reviewed both the submitted Daylight and Sunlight Assessment (September 2024) and a Sun Study .In reviewing the Daylight and Sunlight Assessment, whilst Officers recognise that the proposed rear extension would result in some impact on daylight on habitable rooms including the conservatory  at neighbouring no76, overall it is considered that the level of impact would be acceptable. Within this context, it is considered that  there would be no significant loss of daylight to the neighbour. In reviewing the Existing and Proposed Daylight Shadow Study (Winter and Summer Solstice), Offices conclude that none of the south facing residential windows would see an adverse impact. In addition, overshadowing was assessed in terms of the gardens of both nos 72 and 76 Deacon Road concluding there would be no noticeable impact in terms of sunlight access. Officers accept these conclusions. The first floor window at the rear would be sited on a corner with glazing on the side facing towards neighbouring properties. Subject to any side facing glazing being secured as non openable and obscurely glazed, it is considered that this would not give rise to any loss of privacy or perceived overlooking. Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Consultations7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposal and 1 objection has been recieved relating to Excessive height or bulk of buildings. The concern raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Sustainable Transportation- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Conversion of garage into habitable space. Erection of single storey rear and first floor side extension. Changes to fenestrations.Officers note that the proposed first-floor extension would be visible within the streetscene, however, the proposal would not significantly detract from the host dwelling or surrounding area, as multiple dwellings on Bolton Road benefit from a similar extension. Policy Guidance 36, states that first floor side extensions should be set in from the boundary by at least 1m to maintain the existing gaps between properties and the rhythm of gaps. In this case, the applicant has not maintained 1m from the boundary however, the extension would be set down sufficiently. The pitched roof slope would aid in preserving the character and appearance of the streetscene and would not cause harm to the wider area or dwelling.  The proposed single storey rear extension would have a depth of 4.4m and a total pitched roof height of 3.6m. Officers note that the depth would fall outside the guidelines of Policy Guidance 33 of the Residential Design SPD however, the proposed height would make the proposal appear subordinate to the host dwelling. Additionally this aspect of the proposal would not be visible in the streetscene.The applicant proposes similar external materials and proposes to use similar window designs in the construction of this extension.Considering the above, on balance, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the retrospective development, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The existing garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking by failing to comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the demolition of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the applicant proposes the construction of a new garage and the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking. Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Report which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises an end-terrace building comprising a retail store.28 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer comment: The proposed rear extension would replace the existing brick structure at the back. It would have a depth of 5.5m and a modest flat roof height of 3m, it would appear subordinate and proportionate to the building. It would be similar to the rear extension approved at 141 Hook Road under 22/03838/FUL.  As such, overall, officers consider that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The nearest ground floor window that would be affected by the proposed rear extension is neighbouring property No.141 Hook Road and Sydney Court. No.141 Hook Road at ground floor level consists of a retail store and the space is not for residential use purposes. There is sufficient separation distance between the proposal and Sydney Court. Further, the overall depth of the rear structure and side wall would be reduced by the proposal compared to the existing situation. Therefore the sunlight, daylight and outlook impact to side fenestrations at Sydney Court would be reduced. Given its modest scale and appropriate design and position, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. It is considered to comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013)

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission.Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to change the approved planning permission ref:24/02144/HOU; this involves  bringing forward the proposed side garage of the property  bringing it forward to align with that of the existing dwelling. Officers have reviewed the proposed amendments in the context of the approved planning permission ref : 22/02144/HOU. The approved single storey side extension  is compliant with the recommendations as set out in Policy Guidance 35  in the Residential Design SPD  in terms of being set back from the front wall of the original house by at least 500mm.   The proposed  amendments are considered greater than non material  and  would conflict  with the recommendations set out in Policy Guidance 35 and the recommendations as set out in the Officer Report for 22/02144/HOU.
